content: Kronos supports creating or importing plugins to add more database type support.

title: Language pack plugin
content: Kronos supports the creation or introduction of language pack plugins to define Kronos' built-in text prompts.

content: Kronos provides a basic SQL builder that allows you to build SQL operations using named parameters, and this chapter describes how to use this builder to perform operations such as SQL queries.

content: This chapter describes how to create, delete, empty, and synchronize database tables.

title: Welcome to Kronos
content: Kronos is a modern ORM framework for kotlin based on the Code First  pattern, KCP (Compiler Plugin), which supports both JVM and Android platforms.

title: Welcome to Kronos
content:
graph LR
    A[Kronos] --> B[Kronos-core]
    B --> I[ORM for KPojo]
    I --> J[Queryã€Insertã€Updateã€Deleteï¼Œetc.]
    A --> C[Kronos-compiler-plugin]
    C --> L[Kronos-compiler-kotlin-plugin]
    C --> D[Kronos-maven-plugin]
    C --> E[Kronos-gradle-plugin]
    A --> F[Kronos-data-source-wrapper]
    F --> G[DataSource]
    G --> H[Mysql, Sqlite, Postgresql, Oracle, SqlServer, etc.]
    A --> K[Kronos-logging and Other Plugins]

title: Welcome to Kronos
content: Kronos developed for Kotlin, with the expression tree parsing support implemented in KCP and kotlin's generics and higher-order functions, Kronos provides super-expressive, concise, and semantic writing that makes manipulating databases much easier. Based on the Code First philosophy, we provide automatic creation of database table structures, automatic synchronization, and support for table structures, indexes and other operations. At the same time through the compiler plug-in , we realized to provide a reflection-free Pojo and Map interconversion scheme.

title: Welcome to Kronos
content: Kronos cascade operations , cross-table cross-library query greatly improves the development efficiency , and based on the kotlin co-processing mechanism greatly improves the high concurrency performance .

title: Code First
content: ORM (Object-Relational Mapping, Object-Relational Mapping) is a technique for mapping between an object model and a relational database.ORM allows developers to manipulate databases using object-oriented programming without having to write direct SQL statements. In ORM, "Code First" is a development methodology that emphasizes defining database structures from code. Specifically, the developer first defines the data model by writing classes (usually entity classes), and then the ORM framework automatically generates database tables and relationships based on these classes. Here are some key features of Code First:

title: Code First
content: : The developer defines the entity classes and their properties first, rather than designing the database table structure first. This approach allows developers to focus more on business logic.

title: Code First
content: : Many ORM frameworks (such as Entity Framework) support an automatic migration feature that automatically updates the database structure based on changes in the code. This reduces the effort of manually modifying database tables.

title: Code First
content: : The Code First approach makes it easier to make model changes and adjustments during development because the database structure is code driven.

title: Code First
content: : Developers can configure the mapping relationships of entity classes, such as specifying primary keys, foreign keys, column names, etc., through Data Annotations or the Fluent API.

title: Code First
content: : Since the database structure is generated by code, developers can incorporate changes to the data model into a version control system (e.g., Git), which makes team collaboration and code review easier.

title: Code First
content: Suppose we have a simple user entity class:

title: Code First
content: Using Code First, the ORM framework automatically generates a database table named user with the fields id, name and email based on this class.

title: Code First
content: Code First is a convenient and efficient way to approach database development, especially for rapid development and iterative scenarios. It allows developers to manage and maintain the data model directly at the code level, thus increasing development efficiency and flexibility.

title: Data Table Class Definition
content: Declaring a class as a datasheet class in Kronos is very simple, just make the class inherit from KPojo, here is a simple example:

title: Data Table Class Definition
content: In Kronos, we call such a class KPojo, which is a markup interface for marking a class as a Kronos data table class for generic operations. At the same time, kronos adds some properties and methods to the class at compile time to read data table information efficiently.

title: Data Table Class Definition
content: We, recommend declaring the class as data class and adding defaults to it to make the data class more flexible for ORM operations.

title: Data Table Class Definition
content: Note that properties declared by the var keyword can only be modified in the set of update or upsert.

title: Global configuration
content: If you do not specify a data source during database operations, kronos automatically uses this default data source.

title: Global configuration
content: The data source type is KronosDataSourceWrapper, and the creation method can be found at ğŸ“šConnect to database.

title: Global configuration
content: The default data source defaults to NoneDataSourceWrapper, be sure to modify your configuration file before using it.

title: Global configuration
content: Kronos supports multiple data sources and dynamic data sources.

title: Global configuration
content: Multiple data sources: for specific operations, such as KPojo.update.execute(wrapper), other KronosDataSourceWrapper can be passed in the execute function. instances in the execute function, thus using other data sources.

title: Global configuration
content: Dynamic data source: Kronos.dataSource is a function where you can implement your logic to return different instances of the data source, implementing a dynamic data source.

title: Global configuration
content: The table name policy means that by default (no annotated configuration), kronos automatically generates a table name for the database based on the Kotlin class name, e.g. User -> user.

title: Global configuration
content: Creating a custom table naming strategy KronosNamingStrategy is detailed in: concept - naming-strategy .

title: Global configuration
content: We by default provide both LineHumpNamingStrategy and NoneNamingStrategy table name strategies:

title: Global configuration
content: This policy converts kotlin class names to underscore-separated lowercase strings, e.g. ADataClass -> a_data_class This strategy converts database table/column names to camel names, e.g. user_name -> userName.

title: Global configuration
content: This strategy leaves kotlin class names as they are, e.g. ADataClass -> ADataClass, and database table/column names as they are, e.g. user_name -> user_name.

title: Global configuration
content: By default, kronos uses the NoneNamingStrategy table name strategy.

title: Global configuration
content: Similar to the global table name strategy, the column name strategy means that by default, kronos automatically generates column names based on the property name of the Kotlin class, e.g. classId -> class_id.

title: Global configuration
content: The column name strategy class is common to the table name strategy and is set up in the following way:

title: Global configuration
content: Used to set the creation time field for all tables.

title: Global configuration
content: Create time strategy with information on

title: Global configuration
content: Customize the creation of a time strategy by creating a KronosCommonStrategy, see: concept - common strategy ).

title: Global configuration
content: The global default for creating time policies is turned off** and needs to be turned on manually.

title: Global configuration
content: After setting the creation time strategy globally, the global setting can still be overridden in the KPojo class via ğŸ“šAnnotation Settings - @CreateTime Create Time Column.

title: Global configuration
content: Used to set the update time field for all tables (whether on, kotlin attribute name and database column name).

title: Global configuration
content: Update time strategy with information on

title: Global configuration
content: Customize the update time strategy by creating a KronosCommonStrategy, see: concept - common strategy ).

title: Global configuration
content: The update time strategy is turned off by global default and needs to be turned on manually.

title: Global configuration
content: After setting the logic update time policy globally, the global setting can still be overridden in the KPojo class via ğŸ“šannotation-config - @UpdateTime Update Time Column.

title: Global configuration
content: Used to set logical delete fields for all tables (whether on, kotlin attribute name and database column name).

title: Global configuration
content: Customize the logical deletion strategy by creating a KronosCommonStrategy, see: concept - common strategy ).

title: Global configuration
content: The Logical Deletion Policy is turned off by global default and needs to be turned on manually.

title: Global configuration
content: After setting the logic deletion policy globally, the global setting can still be overridden in the KPojo class via ğŸ“šAnnotation Settings - @LogicDelete Logic Delete Columns.

title: Global configuration
content: Used to set the optimistic lock version field for all tables (whether it is on, kotlin attribute name and database column name).

title: Global configuration
content: Optimistic locking (versioning) policy with information on

title: Global configuration
content: Customize the optimistic locking (versioning) strategy by creating a KronosCommonStrategy, see: concepts - common strategy ).

title: Global configuration
content: The optimistic locking strategy is turned off by global default and needs to be turned on manually.

title: Global configuration
content: After setting the optimistic locking policy globally, the global setting can still be overridden in the KPojo class via ğŸ“šAnnotation Settings - @Version Optimistic Locking (Version) Column.

title: Global configuration
content: Used to specify the default format for date formatting, following the ISO 8601 specification, defaulting to yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.

title: Global configuration
content: Kronos uses yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss to format the date/time by default, you can change the default format by the following ways:

title: Global configuration
content: After setting the default date format globally, the global setting can still be overridden in the KPojo class via ğŸ“šAnnotation Settings - @DateTimeFormat date time format.

title: Global configuration
content: Used to specify the default time zone, following the ISO 8601 specification, when creating time, updating time and formatting date/time.

title: Global configuration
content: Kronos uses the current system time zone by default. You can change the default time zone by doing the following:

title: Global configuration
content: Used to set the policy for generating SQL statements when the value in where/having/on etc. conditional statements is null by global default.

title: Global configuration
content: For example, in a query scenario where a condition has a value of null you may want to ignore the query condition or convert it to a condition such as is null, is not null etc. NoValueStrategy strategy for handling null value conditions in different scenarios

title: Global configuration
content: Note that if you are customizing the no-value policy, use the Ignore policy with caution during DELETE and UPDATE operations to avoid full table deletions or full table updates.

title: Global configuration
content: The NoValueStrategy strategy accepts two parameters, the type of operation (SELECT/UPDATE/DELETE) and the statement condition, and returns the NoValueStrategyType, as detailed in:concept - no-value-strategy .

title: Global configuration
content: Deserialize strings in the database to objects at query time, and automatically serialize objects when inserting into the database.

title: Global configuration
content: By creatingKronosSerializeProcessorCustom Serialization Parserï¼Œfor further details, refer toï¼šAutomatic Serialization and Deserialization ã€‚

title: Global configuration
content: For example, a serialization parser can be implemented by introducing the GSON library:

title: Global configuration
content: Here we are using GSON library to implement serialization deserialization parser, you can use any library you like like like Kotlinx.serialization, Jackson, Moshi, FastJson etc.
